newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK's Dragonair suspends A330-300 operations.
newsitem.headline: HK's Dragonair suspends A330-300 operations.

text.p: Hong Kong Dragonair Airlines (Dragonair) said on Saturday it has suspended operations of its four Airbus Industrie A330-300 aircraft due to concerns about the reliability of their Rolls-Royce Trent 700 engines.

"Dragonair has chosen to take the precautionary measure of suspending A330-300 operation until the engine manufacturer can provide sufficient assurance that the reliability problems of the engine are resolved," the company said in a statement.

It said the decision followed a series of Trent 700 engine failures on A330 aircraft of Dragonair and Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd over the past few weeks, with the latest being on a Dragonair A330 aircraft on Friday.
Flight KA-MH061 from Hong Kong made an emergency landing at Subic Bay in the Philippines on Friday after developing engine trouble en route to Kota Kinabalu in Malaysia.

"The most recent failure occured on a brand new component of the engine and the possibility of some form of assembly or quality problem cannot be ruled out until a full inspection has taken place," Dragonair said.
Cathay Pacific also said earlier on Saturday it had suspended operations of its A330-300 fleet of 11 aircraft.
Problems in the Trent 700 engines have forced a series of unscheduled single-engine landings recently.
Dragonair said the problem with an engine part in the Rolls-Royce Trent 700 engine had been "clearly identified and understood" and a long-term design solution had been found.

"However, as standard procedure, this design will have to be endurance tested before it can be released for service," it said. "As a result, Dragonair has decided to avoid exposing its passengers and staff to any level of risk however small."
The carrier said the suspension, with immediate effect, did not affect Dragonair's fleet of seven A320 aircraft powered by IAE V2500 engines.
Swire Pacific Ltd and Cathay Pacific together hold about 26 percent of Dragonair, whose major shareholder is China National Aviation Corp.
